The development of high-performance and low-cost catalysts is of great significance in the field of catalytic hydrogenation. It is advisable to convert the reserved coal gangue waste into new materials with special functions. Therefore, in this work, dual-activated coal gangue was used as support to prepare Ni-based catalysts that could catalyze the hydrogenation of dioctyl phthalate to synthesize di(2-ethylhexyl) hexahydro-phthalate. The conversion of dioctyl phthalate can reach 99.9 % over the Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst using dual-activated coal gangue as support. This catalyst can be recycled 8 times without obvious loss of its initial activity. Characterization and experimental results revealed that both activation treatments have significant impact on surface structure and composition of catalysts. Thermal activation could remove toxic elements such as S and produce a larger specific surface area, while chemical activation could enhance the dispersion of the active metal and the metal-support interaction, which ultimately improved the activity and stability of the catalyst, simultaneously. This strategy provides a good reference for the high-value utilization of coal gangue and the design of excellent catalyst. Graphical abstract The surface structure of the coal ganguesupport is adjusted by aninnovative dual-activatedmethod. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Coal gangue Ni-based catalyst Activating treatment Dioctyl phthalate Hydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction At present, coal is still one of the main energy sources in many countries of the world. Coal gangue (CG), as the main solid waste in the coal production process, possesses huge reserves [1–3]. It has caused a series of resource and environmental problems such as occupying farmland, damaging the ecological environment, and polluting water and atmosphere [4–6]. However, the utilization of CG is mainly concentrated in the manufacture of certain low-end materials, such as adsorbent materials [7], aluminum extraction [8] and construction materials [9], making this abundant mineral resource underutilized. Therefore, researchers have carried out numerous studies on CG in order to realize its high-value utilization. As we all know, CG is mainly composed of clay minerals containing SiO2, Al2O3 and other oxides [10–12], such as quartz, kaolin and hydromica [13], which can be considered as a potential catalytic support material. In this way, replacing the traditional support materials with CG can not only reduce the catalyst cost, but also achieve the high value utilization of CG. Some researchers have therefore attempted to use CG as a catalyst support. For example, Lu et al. used acid-pretreated CG as a catalyst support for the catalytic reforming of toluene, in which high toluene conversion and H2 yield were obtained [14]. However, the acid treatment times are too long for industrial production. Surprisingly, to the best of my knowledge, CG-supported material has still not been investigated in the field of hydrogenation. Catalytic hydrogenation belongs to the atomic economy reaction, which is widely used in pharmaceutical [15], petroleum refining [16], flavorings [17] and other fine chemical industries. Notably, phthalate plasticizers are typically fine chemicals that have been widely used in plastic products, however, they contribute to a series of human health problems such as obesity and cancer due to the existence of aromatic rings in their structure [18]. In order to reduce the harmfulness of phthalates, selective hydrogenation is regarded as the most efficient method to convert them into the environmentally friendly and safe cyclohexane-dicarboxylate plasticizers [19]. Catalysts play an important role in catalytic hydrogenation. Noble metal catalysts have been applied in various hydrogenation processes both in laboratory and industry due to their high activities. However, their high price and low reserves limit their further applications. Nickel and noble metals such as gold can form crystals with a face-centered cubic structure, which has a high degree of symmetry and can accommodate impurities and defects, making it important in the field of catalysis. As an emerging class of metal catalysts, Ni-based catalysts are gradually replacing the traditional noble metal catalysts in hydrogenation [20] due to their abundant reserves, low cost, and high activity. Notably, Ni-based catalysts usually apply as loaded catalysts, where the supports act as a skeleton for loading, dispersing and immobilizing the active species, thereby increasing the activity and stability of the catalyst [21]. Generally, alumina [22], silica [23], molecular sieves [24], and carbon nanotubes [25] are commonly used as the supporting materials. However, due to the weak interactions between the support and metal, the prepared metal catalysts usually exhibited poor stability, which limited their practical applications. Considering CG has low BET surface area and contains certain amount of S, it is not suitable to act as supporting material of catalysts. Changing its chemical composition and internal structure through certain physical and chemical activations are essential to activate CG [26]. In General, there are three ways to activate CG, including mechanical activation, thermal activation and chemical activation. Han et al. investigated the effect of different alkali activators on the extraction efficiency of CG in supercritical water, and found that when NaOH, Na2CO3, and KOH were added as activators, cancrinite, sodalite and kalsilite could be formed, respectively [27]. Shao et al. studied the thermal behavior and chemical reactivity of CG in N2 atmosphere and air atmosphere, and the results showed that the internal mechanism of combustion accelerating CG activation involved the reduction in apparent activation energy required for thermal activation [28]. However, studies on the activation of CG for the hydrogenation performance of CG-supported catalysts are scarce to date. Herein, CG was first activated by both heat treatment and chemical treatment. Then, certain Ni-based catalysts were prepared by a deposition precipitation method using the dual-activated CG as support. The effect of dual-activation on the surface structure of the CG support was systematically investigated, as well as the catalytic performance of CG-supported Ni-based catalysts in dioctyl phthalate (DOP) hydrogenation. It was found that toxic elements such as S were removed from CG support through the dual-activation treatment. A Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst showed a 99.9 % of DOP conversion and a good stability under harsh reaction conditions, which can be attributed to its large specific surface area, good dispersion of the active Ni, and the strong interaction between support and Ni. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals are analytical grade and used without further purification. Raw coal gangue ash (CGA) was purchased from Jinan Zhongbiao Technology Co., Ltd. DOP, n-hexane and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were obtained from Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagent Factory. Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2‧6H2O) was supplied by Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Sodium aluminate (NaAlO2) was obtained from Fuchen Reagent Co., Ltd. Ethanol was purchased from Tianjin East China Reagent Factory. Ultrapure Ar (99.999 %) and 10 vol% H2/Ar were provided by Baoding Jinglian Gas Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of catalyst The preparation of catalyst is mainly includes two parts, namely the activation of the CG and the loading of the active metal (Scheme 1 ). 2.2.1 Activation of supports First of all, the raw CGA was passed through a 200-mesh sieve to obtain the powdered CG, named as CWS. Next, CWS was thermally activated under different atmospheres. CWS were calcined in a muffle furnace at 800 °C for 2 h under air atmosphere (or N2 atmosphere) to obtain the ZMC support (or ZTC support). Finally, the supports were chemically activated. For example, 4.0 g of ZMC, 7.0 g of NaOH and 0.574 g of NaAlO2 were added into 64 mL of deionized water, and aged at 25 °C for 2 h. The mixture was then transferred to a hydrothermal autoclave and heated at 80 °C for a period of time. After that, the precipitate was washed three times with deionized water and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. A series of supports were prepared by the same method with different hydrothermal times, named as ZMC-X (X represents hydrothermal time of 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 h, respectively). ZTC and CWS were also chemically treated by the same method for 1 h, and labeled as ZTC-1 and CWS-1, respectively. 2.2.2 Loading of active metal Ni The loading of active metal Ni was carried out through deposition-precipitation method. For a typical run: 0.62 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 34 mL of deionized water under stirring, and then 0.8 g of ZMC-X was added to disperse evenly. After that, 6 mL of NaOH solution (1 M) was added to the above mixture to keep the pH value at 11–12, and stirred at 40 °C for 4 h. After aging for 8 h, the resulting suspension was filtered, washed with deionized water to pH = 7 and 8, and dried at 80 °C to give a yellow solid. Subsequently, the yellow solid was calcined at 400 °C for 2 h at a heating rate of 1.5 °C/min in air to form a brown precursor. Finally, the precursor was reduced at 450 °C for 2 h under an H2/N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The prepared catalyst is denoted as Ni/ZMC-X. Ni/ZTC-1 and Ni/CWS-1 were prepared by the same method while using ZTC-1 and CWS-1 as supports instead of ZMC-X. The nickel-based catalyst without the addition of coal gangue as support during the catalyst preparation process was named as Ni-block. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a D8 ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer using a Cu Kα radiation source. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, pore volume and pore size distribution were collected from the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms at -196 °C using a Micromeritics Tristar II 3020 specific surface and pore analyzer. Pore volume and pore size distribution were calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed on a JEOL Jem-2100F transmission electron microscope. Surface morphology of the sample was characterized using a Hitachi S4800 scanning electron microscope (SEM). H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was determined on a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy was obtained on a Nicolet IS10 in the frequency range of 4000 to 400 cm−1. Chemical components of the samples were determined by X-ray fluorescence analyzer spectrometer (XRF, Axios, Holland). Elemental contents in the samples were determined on a Vista MPX spectrometer (ICP-OES). 2.4 Catalyst evaluation For a typical run: 4.0 mL of DOP, 0.1 g of catalyst, and 60 mL of n-hexane were added sequentially to a 100 mL stainless steel reactor equipped with a mechanical stirring and electrical heating system. Then, the reactor was charged with H2 to replace the air in it three times. The hydrogenation reaction was then carried out under a hydrogen pressure of 5.0 MPa at 150 °C with a stirring speed of 500 rpm. At the end of the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature. The products were analyzed by an Agilent 7820A gas chromatograph equipped with a hydrogen flame ion detector, and the compositions of the products were identified by a Thermo Trace 1300 gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer (GC–MS). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of catalysts 3.1.1 Effect of support thermal activation on catalytic performance The effect of thermal activation for the CG support on the hydrogenation performance of the prepared Ni-based catalyst was first investigated. The results show that at 150 °C and hydrogen pressure of 5.0 MPa, both the catalyst Ni/CWS-1 supported on the raw CG (without thermal activation treatment) and the catalyst Ni/ZTC-1 supported on the thermally activated CG in N2 atmosphere were nearly not catalytically active for DOP hydrogenation; while under the same conditions, the catalyst Ni/ZMC-1 supported on the activated CG in air could catalyze the hydrogenation reaction with a DOP conversion of 99.9 % (Fig. 1 a). The above results demonstrate that the thermal activation of CG in air is crucial for improving the catalyst's performance. 3.1.2 Effect of support chemical activation time on catalytic performance On the basis of the thermal activation, the effect of chemical activation, specifically hydrothermal time, was further investigated (Fig. 1b). As can be seen, the conversion of DOP was only 14.6 % at 110 °C over the Ni/ZMC-0 catalyst, in which ZMC was not chemically activated before the loading of active Ni. In contrast, the DOP conversion was 31.5 % over the Ni/ZMC-1catalyst, in which the ZMC was treated with hydrothermal alkali for 1 h before Ni loading. Unfortunately, the catalyst activity gradually decreased with further prolonging the hydrothermal alkali treatment time, and the conversion of DOP was only 9.6 % over Ni/ZMC-5, where the hydrothermal alkali treatment of ZMC was carried out for 5 h before loading the active Ni. We speculate that the possible reason for this result might be the destruction of the support structure during the long alkaline pre-treatment. Thus, appropriate hydrothermal alkali treatment of ZMC can markedly improve the catalyst activity due to the regulation on the support structure. 3.1.3 Effect of reaction temperature on catalytic performance The effect of reaction temperature on the catalyst performance was also systematically investigated, and the results demonstrate that the reaction temperature has significant influence on the catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 1c, the conversion of DOP increases with the increase of the reaction temperature over the optimum catalyst Ni/ZMC-1, reaching a maximum value of 99.9 % at 150 °C and maintaining this conversation at higher reaction temperature (170 °C). Similarly, the activities of the other catalysts increase with the increase of the reaction temperature and achieve almost complete conversion (99.9 %) at 170 °C (Fig. S1). It is obvious that their activities at low reaction temperatures (Fig. S1) are all much lower than that of Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst (in Fig. 1c), which further indicates that the hydrothermal alkali pretreating time has remarkable effect on the catalytic activities of the CG-loaded Ni/ZMC catalysts. In addition, comparing the DOP hydrogenation performance of Ni/ZMC-1 (with support) and Ni-block (without support) prepared under optimum conditions (Fig. S2), it can be seen that there is a discontinuous decay of the catalyst activity when there is no support for coal gangue, which indicates that proper treatment of coal gangue support is crucial for improving the activity of nickel catalysts. 3.1.4 Stability of catalysts Considering stability is an important criterion for a catalyst, the durability of the Ni/ZMC catalysts in DOP hydrogenation was evaluated. As can be seen, the Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst shows good stability with the DOP conversion remaining above 90 % after eight runs (Fig. 2 a). Furthermore, the spent catalyst can be quickly separated and recovered with magnets (Fig. 2b), facilitating its operation. In addition, the ion leaching concentration of the catalysts (Table S1), as well as the comparison of the XPS (Fig. S3) and ICP (Table S3) results before and after the eight reactions, show that the changes of the used Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst relative to the fresh catalyst are very small, almost negligible, indicating that the Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst has a strong stability, which is mainly due to the stronger interaction between the metal-support in catalyst Ni/ZMC-1. Conversely, the catalytic activities of the Ni/ZMC-0 and Ni/ZMC-5 catalysts gradually decreased during the stability tests, as shown in Fig. 2c and 2d. The DOP conversions over Ni/ZMC-0 and Ni/ZMC-5 decreased to 77 % and 45 %, respectively, within five runs, demonstrating the poor stabilities of these two catalysts. Thus, for the purpose of preparing a high active and stable CG supported Ni-based catalyst for DOP hydrogenation, air calcination and hydrothermal treatment for 1 h were selected as the optimum CG pretreatment conditions in this work. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts The CG supports with different activated treatments and their Ni-loaded catalysts were first characterized by XRD to confirm the crystalline nature and structure. According to the Fig. 3 a, the dominant mineral phases of the CWS support (sieved GC) were quartz (SiO2, PDF card No. 79-1906), kaolinite (Al2(Si2O5)(OH)4, PDF card No. 78-1996) and illite (KAl2[(OH)2AlSi 3O10], PDF card No. 29-1496) [29–31]. However, after thermal activation, the characteristic peaks of kaolinite (2θ = 12.4, 33.1, 35.1°) disappeared due to the removal of OH− at a high temperature, which destroyed the crystal face structure of kaolinite and transformed kaolinite into amorphous metakaolinite [32]. That is thermal activation can initially change the structure of the GC support. For the reduced Ni-based catalysts with different thermally activated pretreatment supports in Fig. 3b, the XRD patterns are similar to the support, except a new peak at 2θ = 44.5°, which is characteristic of metallic Ni [33], indicating that the structure of the support did not change after the Ni loading and subsequent calcination. It should be pointed out that the peak of Ni in Ni/ZMC-1 is not obvious, indicating a uniform distribution and a small particle size of Ni. Fig. 3c displays the XRD patterns of the chemically activated pretreatment CG at different alkali treatment times. Among them, when the alkali treatment time of the support is 5 h, some new diffraction peaks appeared in ZMC-5, showing a typical characteristic peak of zeolite A [34]. Fig. 3d shows that Ni, which is the active species of these catalysts, has been successfully loaded onto the support, as the characteristic diffraction peak of Ni appearing at 44.5° [35]. The above results confirm that a properly pretreated CG support could inhibit the aggregation of the active components and improve their dispersibility. The composition of the support is another important factor which has a remarkable influence on the activity of the supported catalyst. The chemical compositions of ZMC-0 and ZMC-1 are very similar (Table S2), where the difference is almost negligible. The reason may be that only small amount of SiO2 and Al2O3 on the surface of the support dissolve within a short time, so the overall Si-Al ratio of the support did not change dramatically. With the extension of the alkali treatment time, certain amount of SiO2 and Al2O3 in the support first dissolved, and then some dissolved [SiO4]4− and [AlO4]5− aggregated to form new aluminosilicate structures in the support [32], which is consistent with the change in the diffraction peak in Fig. 3c. Meanwhile, the loss of MgO, Fe2O3 and other components from the ZMC-5 support led to a significant decrease in the activity and stability of the Ni/ZMC-5 catalyst. The physicochemical properties of the CG and Ni-based catalysts supported on activated CG were investigated, and the results are listed in Table 1 . Obviously, CG had the smallest specific surface area. The specific surface areas of the Ni/ZTC-1 and Ni/ZMC-X catalysts were much larger than that of the Ni/CWS-1 catalyst, which can be ascribed to the removal of water and organic substances from CG by the thermal activation treatment [36], forming a porous microstructure and generating more amorphous silica and alumina. In general, as the supports with large specific surface area could facilitate the distribution of the active metal particles, the prepared catalysts with highly dispersed active sites usually show better catalytic performance and reaction efficiency [37]. In this work, Ni/ZMC-1 treated with thermal activation in air shows much higher metal surface area and metal dispersion than Ni/CWS-1 and Ni/ZTC-1 pretreated with thermal activation in N2, demonstrating the positive effect of thermal activation in air on CG. In addition, the Ni/ZMC-1 and Ni/ZMC-5 catalysts exhibit around twice the metal surface area and metal dispersion than Ni/ZMC-0, suggesting the positive effect of chemical activation on CG. Moreover, the chemical activation pretreatment time also had a significant effect on the specific surface area of the catalysts, indicating that the hydrothermal alkali treatment gradually changes the structure and composition of the catalyst, which is in agreement with the results in Fig. 3 and Table S2. Among them, Ni/ZMC-1 has the highest surface area (85.4 m2g−1), pore volume (0.27 cm3g−1), pore diameter (12.6 nm), metal surface area (28.53 m2g−1) and metal dispersion (4.29 %), which may not only facilitate the dispersion and loading of the active Ni, but also promote to the mass transfer of DOP and H2 molecules, consistent with its highest catalytic activity. Fig. 4 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and the pore size distribution curves of the Ni-based catalysts supported on dual-activated CG. It can be seen from Fig. 4a and c that all samples exhibit typical IV isotherms with prominent hysteresis loops in the relative pressure (P/P0 ) range of 0.4–1.0, which is characteristic of mesoporous materials [38,39]. In addition, the typical H3 hysteresis loops indicate that the pore structures are flat seams, cracks and wedge-shaped structures composed of flake granular materials [40]. These structures correspond to the structure of CG (Fig. S4), indicating that the pore structures of these catalysts are lamellar structure [41], and such a structure is conducive to mass transfer during hydrogenation. In Fig. 4b, the pore size distributions of the Ni/CWS-1 and Ni/ZTC-1 catalysts are similar and relatively uniform, both around 5 nm. In contrast, the pore size distributions of the Ni/ZMC-X catalysts markedly vary, which can be attributed to the calcination of CG in air and the subsequent hydrothermal alkali pretreatment (Fig. 4d). It is obvious that the hydrothermal alkali activation could effectively modulate the pore size distribution of the catalysts, and the Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst has a wider pore size distribution. Combined with the data in Table 1, it can be demonstrated that the 1 h hydrothermal alkali treatment can regulate the support surface to the best level, exposing more sites to load the active nickel. SEM images of the prepared Ni-based catalysts were then investigated to elucidate the effect of chemical activation on the GC support and catalyst (Fig. 5 a–c). It was found that all the catalysts have a random layered stacking structure, similar to those of the non-activated CG (Fig. S5), with the surface being rough, loose, irregular, and flaky. This can be mainly attributed to the kaolinite, the major mineral component of CG. During the preparation of these catalysts, the volatiles adsorbed in CG release and cause the char to loosen. Etching of the carbon matrix also occurred due to the reactions between O2 and carbon in the air, which can destroy the original compact structure of CG. Besides, some mineral components in CG, such as kaolinite, can be dehydroxylated to generate metakaolin at 800 °C [42], resulting in an irregular and porous structure. Further inspection reveals that Ni/ZMC-1 has the highest surface roughness, which may be attributed to the use of proper amount of NaOH as an activator. The Si-O-Si and Si-O-Al on the support surface are rapidly dissolved in NaOH to form [SiO4]4− and [AlO4]5− under alkaline conditions [43], thus exposing some inner surface. In this way, a greater number of sites on the inner surface are exposed and the specific surface area is improved. However, while the hydrothermal time prolongs to 5 h, the polymerization reaction generates a new O-Si-O-Al-O three-dimensional network structure and reconstructs new structural materials on the surface [44], leading to a decrease in the specific surface area, which is consistent with the BET results. Fig. 5d–i present TEM spectra and particle size distributions of the Ni/ZMC-0, Ni/ZMC-1 and Ni/ZMC-5 catalysts. It was found that the Ni nanoparticles have no fixed shape, together with observable aggregation, in the Ni/ZMC-0 catalyst (Fig. 5d). Besides, the particle size distribution of Ni in Ni/ZMC-0 is broader (Fig. 5g), generally 3–10 nm, with an average particle size of about 6.3 nm. In contrast, in Fig. 5e for Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst, the Ni nanoparticles are basically spherical with relatively uniform distribution, and the particle size is generally distributed in the range of 3–7 nm, with an average particle size of 4.8 nm, which is significantly smaller than that of the Ni/ZMC-0. This is mainly attributed to the proper hydrothermal alkali treatment on the CG support, which can regulate its surface to the best level, exposing more sites to load the highly-dispersed and ultrasmall Ni nanoparticles. From the TEM images of the Ni/ZMC-5 (Fig. 5f), the Ni particles are also basically spherical with a particle diameter of about 6.9 nm. Furthermore, the comparison between the optimal catalyst and the comparison catalysts shows that the Ni nanoparticles in Ni/ZMC-1 have the smallest particle size and highest dispersion, which is an important factor for the highest catalytic activity of the Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst. High-resolution TEM image of the Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst shows clear lattice fringes with a lattice spacing of 0.203 nm (Fig. 6 a), which belongs to the d-spacing of the (111) plane in the cubic Ni [45]. HAADF-STEM image and elemental mapping with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) demonstrate that the active Ni is uniformly dispersed in the Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst (Fig. 6b, d). Moreover, the elements mapping images also confirm the homogeneous distribution of the Si, as well as Al, Ca, Fe and Ti in the CG support (Fig. 6e-i), which is consistent with the literature report regarding the presence of Ca, Fe, Ti and other trace elements in CG [46]. Moreover, the EDS spectra in Fig. S6 prove the existence of Al, Ca, Fe, and Ti elements. In addition, the perfect overlap among Ni, Si and other elements confirms that the intimate contact between the active Ni and the dual-activated CG support in the Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst (Fig. 6c). XPS was first carried out to verify the role of the support composition on the catalyst activity. As can be seen, the composition, especially sulfur, of the Ni-based catalysts supported on CG treated in air or N2 atmosphere varies considerably (Fig. 7 a). The signal-to-noise ratio within the S region for Ni/ZMC-1 of the measured XPS spectra was too low to perform any meaningful interpretation, whereas the S region in Ni/ZTC-1 was obvious, demonstrating the existence of certain amount of S in this catalyst. The characteristic peaks distributed around 156.01 and 163.29 eV, with a satellite peak near 162.41 eV in the S spectrum of Ni/ZTC-1 indicate the presence of organic sulfur in the surface regions [47]. Combined with the reaction results and the absence of S element in Ni/ZMC-1, it is plausible that the presence of S could poison to the Ni active sites, thereby markedly reducing the activity and stability of the Ni-based catalysts. This may be the main reason why the Ni/ZTC-1 catalyst has a suitable specific surface area and higher Ni metal dispersion, but poor catalytic activity in DOP hydrogenation. In order to verify the chemical states of the metals and the interaction between metal and support, XPS characterizations were performed on the Ni/ZMC-0, Ni/ZMC-1 and Ni/ZMC-5 catalysts (Figs. 7a and S7). First, the full spectra (Fig. S7) show that only three characteristic peaks of C 1s, Ni 2p and O 1s can be found in these catalysts. Further analysis of the high-resolution XPS spectra of Ni 2p3/2 in the reduced catalysts reveals three peaks at about 852, 856 and 861 eV, respectively (Fig. 7b). Specifically, the first peak is attributed to the metallic Ni, whereas the second peak and the last peaks represent NiO and its satellite peak [48], which are mainly formed by the oxidation of metallic Ni in air during the sample transportation prior to XPS analysis. Previous literature reports suggest that the binding energy of metallic Ni can affect the stability of the catalyst [49,50]. Generally speaking, the greater the binding energy of metallic Ni, the better the stability of the catalyst. In contrast, a low binding energy of metallic Ni results in poor catalyst stability that is more susceptible to factors like heat, acidity, and alkalinity, ultimately leading to decreased activity. For instance, when exposed to high temperatures, metallic Ni can react with surrounding media, resulting in catalyst deactivation. A catalyst with high binding energy for metallic Ni, however, demonstrates good stability and can maintain high catalytic activity across various conditions. For supported Ni based reforming catalysts, increasing the strength of metal-support interaction not only enhances catalytic activity, but also inhibits the aggregation of metal Ni particles, thereby improving the stability of the catalyst. Apparently, the binding energy of metallic Ni in Ni/ZMC-1 was higher than that in Ni/ZMC-0 and Ni/ZMC-5, demonstrating that the interaction between Ni and support in Ni/ZMC-1 is stronger than those of the other two catalysts, which is consistent with the stability results (Fig. 2) that Ni/ZMC-1 has the best stability in DOP hydrogenation. The FT-IR spectrum of the supports are shown in Fig. 7c. It is obvious that the absorption spectra of the ZMC-0, ZMC-1 and ZMC-5 supports are approximately the same, and the peaks at 1000 cm−1, 790 cm−1 and 455 cm−1 correspond to the asymmetric tensile vibration peak, symmetric stretching vibration peak and bending vibration peak of Si-O-Si, respectively [44]. Otherwise, the Al-O-Si was confirmed by the bending vibration bands at 550 cm−1. Compared with ZMC-0 and ZMC-5, the absorption vibration peak band of ZMC-1 at about 1000 cm−1 became broader, and the central area of the peak shifted from 960 to 1008 cm−1 (red shift). This may be due to the growth interaction of [SiO4]4− and [AlO4]5− in the solution on the surface of ZMC-1 [51], as well as the effect of alkali, which destroys the skeletal structure of the support surface. However, the spectra of ZMC-0 and ZMC-5 show the presence of similar functional groups on the surface of the supports. It is assumed that after 5 h of hydrothermal treatment, the aluminosilicates were reconstructed on the surface of the support [52], which is in agreement with the XRD and BET results. The reducibility of the as-prepared catalysts was evaluated by the H2-TPR. As shown in Fig. 7d, all catalysts have two main reduction peaks, the lower temperature reduction peaks at 305–325 °C and the higher temperature reduction peaks at 447–470 °C. The lower temperature reduction peaks can be attributed to the reduction of bulk NiO having weak interaction with the support, whereas the higher temperature reduction peaks belong to the reduction of NiO having strong interaction with the ZMC support. Obviously, Ni/ZMC-1 has the highest higher temperature reduction peaks at 470 °C, in good agreement with its best stability. Finally, the Ni/ZMC-1 catalysts before and after 8 times of reaction were compared and analyzed. XRD diffraction patterns (Fig. S8) and FT-IR absorption curves (Fig. S9) of the used catalyst were basically the same as those of the fresh catalyst, which proves the excellent stability of the Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst. In addition, compared with the catalysts in previous literatures (Fig. 8 a and Table S4), the Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst prepared in this work have outstanding advantages and development potential in hydrogenation, comparable to noble metal catalysts. The reaction mechanism for the hydrogenation of DOP could presumably be summarized and illustrated in Fig. 8b. The catalytic hydrogenation of DOP is a hydrogenation reaction that involves hydrogenating a benzene ring containing an electron-withdrawing substituent. The chemical stability of the benzene ring is enhanced due to its resonance hybrid structure, which makes its hydrogenation a challenging process [56]. Previous studies have shown that benzene rings are physically adsorbed and flat during hydrogen adsorption. The adsorption energy of Ni (111) is -1.07 eV according to a previous study [18]. Since it is relatively low, DOP has a stronger adsorption capacity for Ni (111). The adsorption process for the hydrogenation reaction of benzene rings is typically divided into two steps: first, the adsorption of hydrogen atoms; second, the metal atoms on the catalyst adsorb hydrogen to form metal hydrides, followed by the transfer of hydrogen atoms. The π electrons within the benzene ring react with the metal hydrides, causing the transfer of hydrogen atoms occurs to form cyclic aromatic compounds. This process is recurrent, replacing all unsaturated bonds until the ring is fully saturated with hydrogen. The superior performance of the Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst should lie in the activation of the support. During the preparation process, (i) the porous structure, induced by the heat treatment, effectively promoted the mass transfer efficiency during the catalytic hydrogenation process; likewise, the organic sulfur was eliminated by the thermal activation pretreatment, and then markedly reduced the poisoning of catalyst. (ii) The alkali treatment adjusted the composition ratio of the support, influenced the electronic structure of the active metal Ni, and thus enhanced the interaction between the active Ni and the support. The combination of these two factors promotes the formation of Ni particles with small particle size and high dispersion, as well as the removal of the toxic organic sulfur, and obtains highly active and stable Ni-based supported catalyst Ni/ZMC-1. 4 Conclusions In summary, a dual activation strategy, including air calcination and hydrothermal alkali treatment, was employed to simultaneously activate CG, which was then used as the support to prepare Ni-based catalysts for DOP hydrogenation. Experimental results showed that the prepared Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst exhibited the best catalytic performance, while the CG support was first calcined in air at 800 °C and then hydrothermal treated in alkali solution for 1 h. The DOP conversion can reach 99.9 % and the selectivity for DEHHP is over 99 % under the optimized reaction conditions. Notably, Ni/ZMC-1 also showed high stability, comparable to some noble metal catalysts. TEM and BET characterizations revealed that thermal activation plays an important role in eliminating toxic organic sulfur and adjusting the structure of the CG support. On the other hand, BET and TPR characterizations demonstrated that chemical activation improved the specific surface area and enhanced the metal-support interactions. This novel dual activation strategy is responsible for the excellent catalytic performance of the Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst. This study not only illustrates the catalytic activity regulation of Ni-based catalysts by the activation of support, but also provides a useful strategy for the green and high-value utilization of solid waste CG. coredata.dc:description: The development of high-performance and low-cost catalysts is of great significance in the field of catalytic hydrogenation. It is advisable to convert the reserved coal gangue waste into new materials with special functions. Therefore, in this work, dual-activated coal gangue was used as support to prepare Ni-based catalysts that could catalyze the hydrogenation of dioctyl phthalate to synthesize di(2-ethylhexyl) hexahydro-phthalate. The conversion of dioctyl phthalate can reach 99.9 % over the Ni/ZMC-1 catalyst using dual-activated coal gangue as support. This catalyst can be recycled 8 times without obvious loss of its initial activity. Characterization and experimental results revealed that both activation treatments have significant impact on surface structure and composition of catalysts. Thermal activation could remove toxic elements such as S and produce a larger specific surface area, while chemical activation could enhance the dispersion of the active metal and the metal-support interaction, which ultimately improved the activity and stability of the catalyst, simultaneously. This strategy provides a good reference for the high-value utilization of coal gangue and the design of excellent catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Fabrication of dual-activated coal gangue-loaded nickel-based catalyst for dioctyl phthalate hydrogenation
